publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

msIdentifier.repository: Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)

history.provenance: found in SubešiOuest, grande enceinteduring M 777.2

seg.seg: A ... flower [is] to be put [lit. made] into the fire as an oblation, [and] the bought [goods] are (so)ld. 10. In [the lunar mansion] Hastā [if] one intends to make subject living beings, any kind of cereal, any kind of ..., (any kind of flo)wer [is] to be put [lit. made] into the fire as an oblation, [and] the living beings be(come) subject. (11). In [the lunar mansion] Svāti (who)
In Svāti soll [der], (dem) Alkohol Sorge machen sollte, ein Stück von der Frucht der Mandanā in die Tür quetschen. Der Alkohol schwindet.
In Svāti, let [him] (who) should be worried by alcohol, squeeze a piece of the Mandanā fruit in the door. The alcohol disappears.

should be careful with wine, a piece of the madana fruit [= Randia dumetorum] [is] to be mashed in the door, [and] the wine will disappear. 13. In [the lunar mansion] Suśākhā a piece [thorn?] of khadira [wood] [= Acacia catechu] [is] to be crushed in the door, in whose name one does [that], this one will be destroyed. [If] one pulls [it] out, [it means] release [= Skt. mokṣaḥ]. 14.

In [the lunar mansion] Anurādhā powder of human bones [is] to be made and then a puppet [is] to be fashioned. Thereupon the head of this puppet should be cut off with a sharp knife. In whose name one does [it], this one before long will [lit. goes to] perish. 15. In [the lunar mansion] Pūrvāṣādhā [if] one dis(plays?) gall from the ...,

one has to cast [lit. make] a spell seven times. In whose names one strews [= the gall] in the door, in this house the people become [like] the Licchavi [people]. 17. In [the lunar mansion] Śrāvana a splitter of human bones [is] to be made; it has to be crushed on the passage of the enemy, [and] his strength will recede.

But if one pulls [it] out, [it means] release [= Skt. mokṣaḥ]. 21. In [the lunar mansion] Śatabhiṣā, in whose name one puts [lit. makes] grain of Michelia champaka [= magnolia] in the fire as an oblation, this one will never be able to do any evil to anyone. 23. In [the lunar mansion] Pūrvabhādrapadā, [aiming] at the perishing of an enemy one should grind

a flower from the garland of a dead one. And then a puppet has to be fashioned, one should cast a spell 108 times [over it] and [it] should definitely be thrown into the fire. In whose name one does [it], before the end of one week he perishes [lit. goes to perishing]. 24. In [the lunar mansion] Aśvinī, oil [and] morośka [plants] [are] to be put [lit. made] into the fire as an oblation.
Im [Mondhaus] Aśvinī soll man Öl und Morośkas im Feuer als Spende darbringen. Unter wessen Namen er [es] tut, dessen Leben wird von Liebe ergriffen.
In [the lunar mansion] Aśvinī one shall offer Oil and morośkas in the fire as an oblation. In whose name he does [it], this one's life will be seized by love.
In whose name one does [it], he will keep his life with pleasure. 27. In the Brahmadattakalpa [ritual] the anterior section is finished. Sanskrit
of Māladaṇḍī [has] to be spoken seven times from the beginning. Sanskrit

p.note: The text has some careless spellings and omissions of akṣaras (11 for 10, ; karstālya [sic!] for karstālya, ; ś ‹r› āwaṃne, ; campaṃ for campäṃ, ; omission of numbers) and in addition late/colloquial forms (omission of anusvāra; degemination; āśe for āśce, ; etve for entwe, , ; osne for ostne, ); note esp. ṣukau for ṣukt kauṃ 'seven days, week' in and further the spelling tverene for twerene in .
yamaṣäle (often) looks like a compromise spelling for standard yamaṣṣälle and late/colloquial yamaṣle (thus in a3).

An almost complete leaf with damages on top of the recto side and on the left side. The lines on the verso side are even, while on the recto side the line distance and script size varies. On the verso there is mostly Sanskrit text, which begins in a 7 (with the exception of a Tocharian sentence in b4-b5). Note that the start of the Sanskrit text in a7 is not marked by any interpunctation.

This leaf immediately follows , which ended with the lunar mansion Uttaraphalguṇī. This is the tenth lunar mansion, according to the Sanskrit order. Therefore, one would expect the number 10 here; the eleventh lunar mansion, Hastā, correctly follows. Accordingly, one has to restore the number 11 in the lacuna. Maybe the scribe was confused due to the start of a new leaf. The other lunar mansions mentioned on this leaf received the correct number of Sanskrit tradition. To be sure, some of the 28 lunar mansions are missing in the following description; one may conceive that these were considered unsuitable for this kind of magic.
For the phrase keto mäsk- 'to be destroyed', cf. TA [[kat]] yām- 'to destroy' 97b.

Pace Filliozat, at the end of the line one has to read pal[ly]īyeṣṣe pit sau –. Since we would expect a subjunctive form, one may think of a restoration to sau(kaṃ), a 3.sg. active from a full-grade subjunctive stem of sukā- ‘± bring’.

The (no doubt negative) meaning of the phrase ‘to become a litsāvi’ is unclear, although the form litsāvi itself ought to be a borrowing from Skt. licchavi-, a name of a people (which also somehow fits with the collective śāmñe 'people'). ts as alternative spelling for cch is already attested in Buddhist Sanskrit (see 462b). In some Sanskrit and Pāli narratives these are known for their rudeness on the one side and for displaying colorful clothes and appearances on the other side. Since pit ‘gall’ is in Indian medicine connected with skin diseases, one may tentatively surmise that ‘becoming a licchavi’ referred to a kind of colored skin disease. For the Licchavis in Indian narratives, see 66-75.

554 sets up a form yoñiyene '± ' groin, pubis’ also said to be attested in b6 yoñiyeṣṣe. He translates: "one [is] to jab a sliver of human bone into the groin of [the effigy of] the enemy; his strength declines". However, in this passage there is no mention made of a puppet as is explicitly done in a3 and a6. We therefore analyze the form as the locative of the well-known word for ‘way, passage, domain' with late/colloquial e for ai. This sound change is actually attested in the preceding leaf (ce for cai in PK AS 8A b7).
In the construction ṣalype wai morośkaṃ we have two subjects but a singular predicate.

list.item: Georges-Jean Pinault (in collaboration with Melanie Malzahn)

a1. This leaf immediately follows [[PK AS 8A]], which ended with the lunar mansion Uttaraphalguṇī. This is the tenth lunar mansion, according to the Sanskrit order. Therefore, one would expect the number 10 here; the eleventh lunar mansion, Hastā, correctly follows. Accordingly, one has to restore the number 11 in the lacuna. Maybe the scribe was confused due to the start of a new leaf. The other lunar mansions mentioned on this leaf received the correct number of Sanskrit tradition. To be sure, some of the 28 lunar mansions are missing in the following description; one may conceive that these were considered unsuitable for this kind of magic.

a2. For the phrase keto mäsk- 'to be destroyed', cf. TA [[kat]] yām- 'to destroy' [[Carling, DThTA]]: 97b.

a3. Pace Filliozat, at the end of the line one has to read pal[ly]īyeṣṣe pit sau –. Since we would expect a subjunctive form, one may think of a restoration to sau(kaṃ), a 3.sg. active from a full-grade subjunctive stem of sukā- ‘± bring’.

a4. The (no doubt negative) meaning of the phrase ‘to become a litsāvi’ is unclear, although the form litsāvi itself ought to be a borrowing from Skt. licchavi-, a name of a people (which also somehow fits with the collective śāmñe 'people'). ts as alternative spelling for cch is already attested in Buddhist Sanskrit (see [[Edgerton BHSD]]: 462b). In some Sanskrit and Pāli narratives these are known for their rudeness on the one side and for displaying colorful clothes and appearances on the other side. Since pit ‘gall’ is in Indian medicine connected with skin diseases, one may tentatively surmise that ‘becoming a licchavi’ referred to a kind of colored skin disease. For the Licchavis in Indian narratives, see [[Law 1922]]: 66-75.

a4. [[Adams, 2DoT]]: 554 sets up a form yoñiyene '± ' groin, pubis’ also said to be attested in [[PK AS 8A]] b6 yoñiyeṣṣe. He translates: "one [is] to jab a sliver of human bone into the groin of [the effigy of] the enemy; his strength declines". However, in this passage there is no mention made of a puppet as is explicitly done in a3 and a6. We therefore analyze the form as the locative of the well-known word for ‘way, passage, domain' with late/colloquial e for ai. This sound change is actually attested in the preceding leaf (ce for cai in PK AS 8A b7).

The text has some careless spellings and omissions of akṣaras (11 for 10, a1; karstālya [sic!] for karstālya, a3; ś ‹r› āwaṃne, a4; campaṃ for campäṃ, a5; omission of numbers) and in addition late/colloquial forms (omission of anusvāra; degemination; āśe for āśce, a3; etve for entwe, a3, a6; osne for ostne, a4); note esp. ṣukau for ṣukt kauṃ 'seven days, week' in a6 and further the spelling tverene for twerene in a4.

yamaṣäle (often) looks like a compromise spelling for standard yamaṣṣälle and late/colloquial yamaṣle (thus in a3).

a6. In the construction ṣalype wai morośkaṃ we have two subjects but a singular predicate.

a1 A ... flower [is] to be put [lit. made] into the fire as an oblation, [and] the bought [goods] are (so)ld. 10. In [the lunar mansion] Hastā [if] one intends to make subject living beings, any kind of cereal, any kind of ..., (any kind of flo)wer [is] to be put [lit. made] into the fire as an oblation, [and] the living beings be(come) subject. (11). In [the lunar mansion] Svāti (who) a2 should be careful with wine, a piece of the madana fruit [= Randia dumetorum] [is] to be mashed in the door, [and] the wine will disappear. 13. In [the lunar mansion] Suśākhā a piece [thorn?] of khadira [wood] [= Acacia catechu] [is] to be crushed in the door, in whose name one does [that], this one will be destroyed. [If] one pulls [it] out, [it means] release [= Skt. mokṣaḥ]. 14. a3 In [the lunar mansion] Anurādhā powder of human bones [is] to be made and then a puppet [is] to be fashioned. Thereupon the head of this puppet should be cut off with a sharp knife. In whose name one does [it], this one before long will [lit. goes to] perish. 15. In [the lunar mansion] Pūrvāṣādhā [if] one dis(plays?) gall from the ..., a4 one has to cast [lit. make] a spell seven times. In whose names one strews [= the gall] in the door, in this house the people become [like] the Licchavi [people]. 17. In [the lunar mansion] Śrāvana a splitter of human bones [is] to be made; it has to be crushed on the passage of the enemy, [and] his strength will recede. a5 But if one pulls [it] out, [it means] release [= Skt. mokṣaḥ]. 21. In [the lunar mansion] Śatabhiṣā, in whose name one puts [lit. makes] grain of Michelia champaka [= magnolia] in the fire as an oblation, this one will never be able to do any evil to anyone. 23. In [the lunar mansion] Pūrvabhādrapadā, [aiming] at the perishing of an enemy one should grind a6 a flower from the garland of a dead one. And then a puppet has to be fashioned, one should cast a spell 108 times [over it] and [it] should definitely be thrown into the fire. In whose name one does [it], before the end of one week he perishes [lit. goes to perishing]. 24. In [the lunar mansion] Aśvinī, oil [and] morośka [plants] [are] to be put [lit. made] into the fire as an oblation. a7 In whose name one does [it], he will keep his life with pleasure. 27. In the Brahmadattakalpa [ritual] the anterior section is finished. Sanskrit b1-b3 Sanskrit b4 Sanskrit This invocation b5 of Māladaṇḍī [has] to be spoken seven times from the beginning. Sanskrit b6 Sanskrit

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a1-2 In Svāti soll [der], (dem) Alkohol Sorge machen sollte, ein Stück von der Frucht der Mandanā in die Tür quetschen. Der Alkohol schwindet. 115
a6-7 Im [Mondhaus] Aśvinī soll man Öl und Morośkas im Feuer als Spende darbringen. Unter wessen Namen er [es] tut, dessen Leben wird von Liebe ergriffen. 241, 258

An almost complete leaf with damages on top of the recto side and on the left side. The lines on the verso side are even, while on the recto side the line distance and script size varies. On the verso there is mostly Sanskrit text, which begins in a 7 (with the exception of a Tocharian sentence in b4-b5). Note that the start of the Sanskrit text in a7 is not marked by any interpunctation.

This leaf immediately follows [[PK AS 8A]].
